posts.name: Aiden Townsend
posts.cooked:
Our team is getting sticky faults from our PCM which are causing the compressor and solenoids to periodically stop. It will have an “episode” every once in a while where the pneumatic system of the robot begins switching on and off every few seconds.

When running the self-test on Phoenix Tuner, we found that the sticky fault was in that the compressor current was too low.

We’ve replaced the pressure switch, the wires to the pressure switch, the compressor, the wires to the compressor, and the entire PCM. The only things we haven’t replaced are the solenoids but if the compressor current is too low then that wouldn’t be the problem. I would expect it to be a wiring problem but we replaced all the wires.

Can anyone offer any advice?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Aidenatgt:

Our team is getting sticky faults from our PCM which are causing the compressor and solenoids to periodically stop. It will have an “episode” every once in a while where the pneumatic system of the robot begins switching on and off every few seconds.

Let me rework this a little bit to something that makes a bit more sense to me… It’s a bit pedantic, but precision is often required when doing this sort of software+electrical+mechanical system debugging.

You observe occasional, unexpected compressor stops when the pressure is still low enough that it should be running.

You simultaneously observe solenoids de-energize when the compressor stops, but do not expect them to be de-energizing at that time.

You observe sticky faults present simultaneously. “Current too low” would imply some flavor of “open circuit” fault between the PCM and the compressor itself.

Can you confirm the above symptoms accurate down to the details?

What I’m looking to try to eek out here is some cause-effect relationships, to move us from “symptom” to “root cause”. A few more questions to help guide that:

Have sticky faults been reset at any point in this process? Since they’re “sticky”, they could have been caused by any problem that occurred between the last reset and now, and therefor wouldn’t necessarily correlate to an issue currently present in your robot’s systems.

Can you describe the symptom in more detail? Like, when you say “switch off”, does that imply that all the lights on the PCM turn off simultaneously? Or, do just some lights go red and others stay on/green?

What other devices are connected to the CAN bus? What does the driver station report for CAN bus load? Are there lots of CAN bus faults?

Got software you can post? It’s a bit of a shot in the dark, but sometimes the issues can be spotted by inspection.

Got any pictures of the PCM , compressor, and robot setup? Again, shot in the dark here, but sometimes issues can be spotted on inspection with a fresh set of eyes.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: Screenshots of the exact thing you see in Phoenix tuner might also help – this ensures nothing gets lost in translation, so to speak.  What gauge wires are you using for the compressor?

posts.name: Ender Wiggin
posts.cooked:
If you want to try a quick fix it sounds like the wires on your compressor are getting disconnected. I would spend your time there to see if somehow the wires to the compressor are getting disconnected. Shake them, pull them see if you can reproduce the failure. If you can replace the compressor and do the same tests.

If this does not solve your problem follow the posts above. ^

posts.name: Aiden Townsend
posts.cooked:
Your description of the symptoms is accurate.

Yes, we reset the faults, and it came back while the robot was sitting still doing nothing.

The PCM status light will slow flash orange whenever the pneumatics are “off”, while the light is flashing the solenoids will not change state and the compressor will not run.

There are a lot of motor controllers, a few CANcoders, and a pdp as well as the pcm, and there are a few CAN faults at the beginning of the program, but they stop almost immediately and existed before we started having the problem.

https://github.com/FRC4188/2021_Bahkar

I’ll get pictures in a minute.

posts.name: Aiden Townsend
posts.cooked: 20 gauge, but we’ve tested with 14 gauge.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
image 823×494 142 KB

image 823×494 142 KB

image 823×494 142 KB

FWIW, you need at least 18 gauge to be legal.  Probably not the cause here, but you should switch.  Same goes for the power wire coming into the PCM.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
ok. nothing too crazy there. I took a look through the code, couldn’t see anything that would obviously explain the behavior. I would concur, based on the details you provided, it appears to be electrical, and between the PCM and the compressor?

Just to be sure you had it - CTRE’s manual has a pretty detailed description of status light behavior. It does appear that a sticky fault might cause it to lock all solenoids in a disabled state? If I’m reading the tables right?

For the compressors you tried, any thoughts on their age and trustworthiness? I assume they are legal FRC compressors, and unlikely to both have internal electrical issues?

One last thing to confirm… I assume PheonixTuner and the PCM’s firmware are all up to date and latest versions?

It may be worthwhile getting in touch with CTRE as well… they can point to more detailed info about exactly what the current draw thresholds and debouncees are which trigger that fault, which might provide additional hints to root cause?
